author: vexx32
body:
# Steps to reproduce

```ps1
function Get-ParameterInformation {
    [CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName = "Set_A")]
    param(
        [Parameter(Mandatory, Position = 0, ParameterSetName = "Set_A")]
        [Parameter(Mandatory, Position = 0, ParameterSetName = "Set_B")]
        [string]
        $Path,

        [Parameter(Mandatory, ParameterSetName = "Set_C")]
        [Parameter(Mandatory, ParameterSetName = "Set_D")]
        [Parameter(Mandatory, ParameterSetName = "Set_E")]
        [string]
        $LiteralPath,

        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = "Set_A")]
        [Parameter(Mandatory, ParameterSetName = "Set_C")]
        [switch]
        $UseCulture,

        [Parameter(Mandatory, ParameterSetName = "Set_B")]
        [Parameter(Mandatory, ParameterSetName = "Set_D")]
        [char]
        $Delimiter,

        [Parameter(Mandatory, ValueFromPipeline, ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName)]
        [PSObject]
        $InputObject
    )

    $PSBoundParameters
}
```

Using this test function that simply binds parameters and then outputs the bound parameters and their values, run the following lines of code:

```powershell
Get-ParameterInformation -InputObject "Named input" -LiteralPath "dummyPath"
"Piped input" | Get-ParameterInformation -LiteralPath "dummyPath"
```

# Expected behavior

```none
Key         Value
---         -----
LiteralPath dummyPath
InputObject Named input

Key         Value
---         -----
LiteralPath dummyPath
InputObject Piped input
```

# Actual behavior

```none
Key         Value
---         -----
LiteralPath dummyPath
InputObject Named input

Get-ParameterInformation: Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters.
One or more parameters issued cannot be used together or an insufficient number of parameters were provided.
```

# Parameter Binding Trace Information

<details>
<summary>Trace Log (Piped Input - Breaks)</summary>


<details>
<summary>**Trace Log (Named Input - Works)**</summary>


comments.author: powercode
comments.body: @vexx32 Which parameterset do you expect to be selected?

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
The same one both times -- `Set_E`

The same parameters are provided both times, but only when using pipeline input it fails.

comments.author: powercode
comments.body: Sure, but InputObject is available for all parameter sets, so how can PowerShell know if you are intending C, D or E?

comments.author: powercode
comments.body: This has nothing do to with the input being passed ByValue by the way. Parameter sets are found by matching specified parameters, not by looking at non-specified once.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> Sure, but InputObject is available for all parameter sets, so how can PowerShell know if you are intending C, D or E? In the "without pipeline" version can tell it is not C because useCulture is mandatory in C and it can tell it is not D because delimiter is mandatory in D. Their absence lets it select E if literalpath is specified. If not it will fall back to the default set and prompt for path. Back in 2016 I wrote https://jhoneill.github.io/powershell/2016/11/30/ParameterPecularities.html explaining that when you pipe something in it cannot use the _absence_ of a parameter to make decisions about parameter sets. The is a workaround, add `ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName` to the declarations that put useCulture in set C and delimiter in Set D. As far as I can see, things written on 5 which relied this are unchanged on 7
Powershell Piped Parameter Peculiarities (and a Palliative pattern!)
PowerShell (or PWSH if you prefer). Devops (especially Azure Devops), Photography, and general thoughts

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: It's good that there's a workaround, but it'd be nicer if the binder could be fixed 😉

title: Parameter Binding - Fail to bind when passing pipeline input ByValue
